titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Sarah Streeter Lester papers 1978.056
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-28 18:19:11 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Sarah Streeter Lester papers contain a 1731 bond between Joris Rapalje and Hendrick Suydam; a deed between Benjamin Hildreth and Benjamin Birdsall, 1788; and a resolution honoring Peter Wyckoff from his employees, 1855.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Sarah Streeter Lester, date unknown. The papers were formally accessioned in 1978.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder with no particular arrangement.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Sarah Streeter Lester was the daughter of Milford B. and Sarah Maria Wyckoff Streeter, authors of The Wyckoff Family in America: A Genealogy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Sarah Streeter Lester papers, 1978.056, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Sarah Streeter Lester papers contain a 1731 bond between Joris Rapalje and Hendrick Suydam of Brooklyn; a deed for Benjamin Hildreth's purchase of New York City property from Benjamin Birdsall, 1788; and a resolution honoring Peter Wyckoff from his employees, 1855.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
